column3: The Trustees of People for Dharma, an NGO led by women, approached the Supreme Court to represent them as intervenors as they sought to understand who controlled temples and how. Coincidentally, this happened around the same time that several myths about temple control were being discussed in the public domain. This is a great example of how women are taking the lead to further the cause of Dharma in India. #WomenLeading #PeopleForDharma #TempleControl #SupremeCourt #India

column3: The Indian Young Lawyers’ Association has been raising awareness on the subject of civil rights and the Constitution. They recently moved a writ petition to the Supreme Court related to the Sabarimala Sree Ayyappa Temple. This case has been taken up by People for Dharma, an NGO led by women and the petition has been received with much enthusiasm. The discussion around civil rights and the Constitution has been gaining momentum and this case is a great opportunity to spread awareness.

column3: The [40426] data mentions the Trustees of People for Dharma, an NGO led by women, and the Indian Young Lawyers' Association in relation to the Sabarimala Sree Ayyappa Temple. The [40555] data reveals that the petition sought entry of women of a reproductive age group into the temple, as well as the removal of restrictions on entry of all genders and ages. The [40682] data states that the petition also sought to end the ban on entry of women of a reproductive age group into the temple. #GenderRights #ReligiousFreedom #WomenRights #Equality

[40555] 9 People for Dharma had previously launched a phenomenally successful campaign seeking the same. [40812] #WomenEmpowerment #SabarimalaTemple #ReligiousFreedom #9PeopleForDharma

column3: This book talks about the petition sought to allow women of a reproductive age group to enter the temple and remove restrictions on their entry as well as entry into places of worship/prayer of other faiths. People for Dharma had launched an international campaign called ‘Ready to Wait’ on behalf of the women who supported the rights of the temple to protect its religious identity. Let's stand together to protect the rights of women in temples and places of worship/prayer! #ReadyToWait #WomenRights #ReligiousFreedom #PeopleForDharma

column3: The phenomenal campaign ‘Ready to Wait’ launched by People for Dharma on behalf of the women who supported the rights of the temple to protect its religious practices, has been a major success.[40812] The campaign has been widely successful in empowering women to take part in places of worship and prayer of other faiths.[40940] People for Dharma has taken up this case on a pro bono basis to further emphasize the need to protect religious practices of temples.[41066] This has been a major breakthrough in the protection of religious practices and has empowered many women to take part in places of worship of other faiths.

column3: Ready to Wait: Women supporting the right of temple to protect its religious practices is an important issue that should be highlighted. People for Dharma took up the case on a pro-bono basis to showcase the sheer diversity of religious practices and the unique character of religious beliefs before the highest court of the land. #ReadyToWait #WomenRights #Dharma #ReligiousPractices #Diversity

column3: The sheer diversity of religious practices and unique character of religious institutions within the Dharmic fold can be seen in the highest court of the land. People for Dharma took up the case on a pro bono basis, which highlighted the rich and varied religious beliefs and deities enshrined within them. It also showcased the position enjoyed by the deities and the importance of religious practices.

column3: The sheer diversity of religious practices in India is something that should be showcased before the highest court of the land. The unique character of religious institutions within the Dharmic fold and the position enjoyed by the deities enshrined within them is something that needs to be highlighted. Moreover, the rights of deities and the devout under the Constitution should be given utmost importance, as well as the serious complications arising from the application of non-Indian laws.

column3: The [41325] text discusses the institutions within the Dharmic fold, and the revered deities enshrined within them. The [41455] text focuses on the rights of deities and devotees under the Constitution, and the complications that arise from the application of non-Indic beliefs and laws to Indian ways of life, faiths, practices, and institutions. The [41587] text presents the potential consequences of this application, including epistemology, theology, and jurisprudence. This data from the book demonstrates the complexity and nuances of religious and cultural identities in India.

column3: The Supreme Court heard several cases regarding the application of non-Indic ontology, epistemology, theology and jurisprudence to the Indian way of life, faiths, practices and institutions [41455]. People for Dharma presented their positions before the three-judge Bench [41587]. The case involved the gods and the devout under the Constitution and the serious complications arising as a result [41716].

column3: The Supreme Court Bench heard several arguments in the case of People for Dharma in October 2017. A Constitution Bench, which typically consists of five judges, was referred to consider the matter. The arguments presented by People for Dharma included iconology, epistemology, theology and jurisprudence to outline various lifestyles, faiths, practices and institutions. Early this year, the Bench delivered its judgment.

column3: The Supreme Court Bench heard several cases on behalf of People for Dharma, including the HRCE Petition and the Sabarimala Temple case. In October 2017, the Bench referred the matter to a Constitution Bench of five judges. By early 2017, the manifest incongruity of having to establish a three-judge Bench to hear cases on behalf of People for Dharma was evident.

column3: The Constitution Bench of India has referred a matter in October 2017 which raised the issue of legitimacy, authenticity and civilization centrality of Indic/Dharmic religious institutions. The petition in the High Court of India has also highlighted the manifest incongruity of having to establish the validity of such institutions before an ostensibly Indian court. This is an important issue that has been raised for discussion in the Indian judicial system.

column3: The Indian civilization has a rich history of religious institutions that have been in existence for centuries. From the 2017 HRCE Petition and the Sabarimala Temple case, it is evident that the struggle to establish the legitimacy, authenticity, and centrality of Indic/Dharmic religious institutions before an ostensibly Indian court is an ongoing one. Despite a demanding professional schedule, this case provided the push to better understand the journey of the Indic civilization.

column3: The Indic/Dharmic religious institutions have been a cornerstone of Indian civilization for centuries. Their legitimacy, authenticity, and centrality to Indian culture have been maintained even in the face of modernity. Pandurang Vaman Kane, Jadunath Sarkar, Radhakumud Mookerji, R.C. Majumdar, K.A. Nilakanta Sastri, and other renowned historians have written extensively on the history and culture of India. Their works have provided insight into the journey of the Indian civilization and are essential to understanding the culture and values of the nation.

column3: The framing of India's Constitution is a fascinating topic that deserves more attention. From the Home Rule Scheme in 1889 until the adoption of the Constitution, India's political system has undergone a significant transformation [43287]. The Constitution is a reflection of India's civilization and captures the essence of the nation's spirit [43415]. B. Shiva Rao's six-volume publication on The Framing of India's Constitution offers an in-depth look into the development of the nation's legal framework and provides a better understanding of the problem [43547].

column3: The Home Rule Scheme of 1889 was an effort to decentralize the Indian government and give local citizens more influence over policy decisions. This movement was a precursor to the adoption of the Constitution in 1950, which established India as a federal state and guaranteed citizens basic rights and freedoms. V.P. Menon's The Story of the Integration of the Indian States and Justice Rama Jois's Legal and Constitutional History of India capture the essence of India's civilization and the spirit of its people. The Framing of India's Constitution: A Study by B. Shiva Rao provides an in-depth look at the process of creating the Constitution and the impact it has had on India.

Additionally, these resources have provided a deep insight into the story of India's integration and its ancient, judicial and constitutional systems.

column3: The integration of Indian states and justice Ram Jois's legal and constitutional system has been an important part of India's history for many decades. From V.P. Menon's The Story of the Integration of the Indian States to Justice Ram Jois's Legal and Constitutional System, many authors have written extensively on Bharat’s journey towards constitutionalism between the 1930s and late 1940s. These writings provide an interesting insight into the development of India's legal and constitutional frameworks. They also serve as a reminder of the importance of preserving India's legal and constitutional heritage.

column3: India has a rich and varied history which is reflected in its ancient, judicial and constitutional systems. These systems provide important lessons on the journey towards constitutionalism. During the 1930s and 1940s, many commentaries were written on the topic, highlighting prevalent thought processes and providing valuable insight. These historical accounts offer a unique perspective into the evolution of the Indian constitution.

column3: The book sheds light on the history and thought processes behind Bharat’s journey towards constitutionalism in the 1930s and 1940s. It provides valuable insight into the lessons learned from the literature related to the Indian civilization worldview, such as the importance of democracy, rule of law, and protection of fundamental rights. Additionally, the book discusses the challenges faced in the path towards constitutionalism and how they were addressed. This provides an opportunity to learn from the past and apply those lessons to the present.

column3: The Sabarimala Sree Ayyappa Temple case, which was taken up for hearings in July 2018 by a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court of India, has triggered an intense debate on the subject of India's civilizational worldview. The case has brought to light the history and prevalent thought processes regarding the issue. Through the literature, we can learn various lessons which can be applied to the case and other related constitutional matters.

column3: The Sabarimala Sree Ayyappa Temple case has been a landmark case in Indian constitutional history, with the Supreme Court of India headed by then Chief Justice of India, Shri Dipak Misra, hearing the case in July 2018. The decision has had a profound effect on the Indian civilizational worldview, with several stalwarts of the legal profession coming to the forefront to support the cause. It has been an important milestone in the evolution of India's constitutional framework and has set a precedent for the protection of constitutional rights. #ConstitutionalMatters #SabarimalaTempleCase #SupremeCourt #DipakMisra

column3: The Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court headed by the then Chief Justice of India, Shri Dipak Misra, took up the significant Sabarimala Sree Ayyappa Temple case for hearings in July 2018. Alongside Senior Advocate Shri K. Parasaran, I was granted the opportunity by the Bench to present detailed arguments on behalf of the petitioners. The case was an important milestone in the ongoing struggle for gender equality in India.

column3: The Supreme Court, headed by former Chief Justice of India, Shri Dipak Misra, recently granted the opportunity to several legal professionals, such as Senior Advocate Shri K. Parasaran, and organizations like People for Dharma and Delhi-based women's organization Chetana to present detailed arguments on the religious practices of the temple. [44454] The arguments sought to explore the religious, social, and cultural implications of the practices and their relevance in society. [44583] The court's decision is expected to have significant implications for the Hindu community and the country as a whole. [44713]

column3: The Supreme Court of India recently granted the opportunity to Senior Advocate Shri K. Parasaran to present detailed arguments on behalf of People for Dharma and Chetana, a Delhi-based women’s organization. These organizations supported the religious practices of the temple, including its right to restrict entry of women of the reproductive age group. Unfortunately, the Court ruled against the temple, denying it the right to restrict the entry of women.

column3: The Constitution Bench of India's Supreme Court recently ruled in favor of the writ petitioners concerning the religious practices of the temple and its rights, including the right to restrict the entry of women of the reproductive age group [44713]. Despite the efforts of Dharma and the Delhi-based women's organization Chetana to support the temple's religious practices [44842], the majority vote of 4-1 on 28 September 2018 ultimately favored the writ petitioners [44971]. This ruling has sparked a heated debate concerning the rights of religious institutions and the rights of women.

column3: The Constitution Bench of India recently ruled in favor of the writ petitioners that the temple's right to restrict the entry of women of reproductive age group was unconstitutional. Several review petitions were moved against this ruling, which were then heard in early 2019. The review petitions acknowledged that the temple had the right to regulate the entry of persons into the temple, however, the entry of women of reproductive age group violated their fundamental right to practice their religion. This ruling has sparked great debates and discussions across the country.

column3: The Indian Constitution Bench ruled in favour of the writ petitioners on 28 September 2018 by a majority of 4-1. Several review petitions were subsequently moved against the ruling which were heard in early 2019. Acknowledging the merit in the review petitions, the Constitution Bench headed by then Chief Justice Shri Ranjan Gogoi framed seven questions of law.

column3: [45101] Petitions have been heard in early 2019 to review the petitions that were moved. The petitions were heard by a Constitution Bench headed by then Chief Justice of India Ranjan Gogoi and referred to a larger nine-judge Bench. [45228] The Bench framed seven questions of law in response to the review petitions which acknowledged the merit of the petitions. [45358] The outcome of proceedings before the nine-judge Bench, known as a 'Reference', is still pending.

column3: The Chief Justice Ranjan Gogoi headed a Constitution Bench which formulated seven questions of law. These questions have now been referred to a larger nine-judge bench. Following this, the next Chief Justice, Sharad Arvind Bobde, has been appointed to preside over the nine-judge bench which will decide on the important constitutional questions.

column3: The nine-Judge Bench has been referred to decide on the constitutional importance of granting security to women of the reproductive age group seeking entry against the temple's religious practice. Chief Justice Shri Sharad Arvind Bobde declined to grant security to any woman of the reproductive age group. This decision by the nine-Judge Bench is pending and will decide the fate of many women who seek entry against the temple's religious practice.

column3: [45487]The Chief Justice Shri Sharad Arvind Bobde has declined to grant security to women of reproductive age group who seek entry against the temple's religious practices and beliefs, thereby restoring the status as it existed prior to the first verdict. [45617]The verdict has been issued in order to protect the rights of women from religious discrimination and to provide them with a safe and secure environment. [45744]The Chief Justice also emphasized the importance of upholding the constitutional rights of all individuals and protecting the sanctity of the temple.

column3: [45617] Women of reproductive age should be given the same security as any other group when seeking entry to Shri Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Kerala. [45744] The Chief Tantri of the Temple restored the status as it existed prior to the first verdict in the first half of 2019. [45872] I had the privilege of representing the Chief Tantri in relation to the Shri Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Kerala. #EqualRights #KeralaTemple #ShriPadmanabhaswamy

column3: Many people are unaware that the Chief Priest of the Chilkur Balaji Temple in Hyderabad and People for Dharma represented the Chief Tantri of the Shri Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Kerala before the Supreme Court in an appeal from 2019. This appeal sought to restore the original status of the temple and its related beliefs prior to the initial verdict. It is an encouraging sign for religious freedom that the Supreme Court has taken such an initiative.

column3: The Chief Tantri of the Shri Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Kerala and the Chief Priest of the Chilkur Balaji Temple in Hyderabad had the privilege of representing People for Dharma before the Supreme Court in an appeal from the 2011 judgement of the Kerala High Court. The High Court had held that the Travancore Royal Family had no authority over the Temple's administration. This is an important achievement for People for Dharma and shows the importance of justice and equality even in matters of religious beliefs.

column3: The Chilkur Balaji Temple in Hyderabad has seen a resurgence of activity lately due to the efforts of the Chief Priest, who has been appealing to the Supreme Court in a case originating from a 2011 Kerala High Court judgment. The judgment stated that the Travancore Royal Family had no authority over the administration of the Padmanabhaswamy Temple after the abolition of royal titles and privileges by the Constitution of India. This has been a major cause for celebration and has breathed new life into the Chilkur Balaji Temple.

column3: The [46126] Kerala High Court made a judgment in 2011 that the Travancore Royal Family had no authority over the administration of the Padmanabhaswamy Temple after the abolition of royal titles and privileges by the Constitution (Twenty-Sixth Amendment) Act of 1971. The High Court also transferred control over the Temple to a trust, which was to be managed by the Government of Kerala. [46258] The trust was created to ensure that the Temple's wealth and assets were preserved for the benefit of the public at large. [46386] The judgment of the High Court was lauded for its fairness and wisdom in addressing an issue that had been in dispute for decades.

column3: The Padmanabhaswamy Temple in Kerala had its royal titles and privileges abolished by the Twenty-Sixth Amendment Act of 1971. As a result, control over the temple was transferred to a trust managed by the appointees of the State Government of Kerala. However, the Supreme Court reversed the verdict of the High Court, allowing the temple to be managed by its own authority.

column3: The Twenty-Sixth Amendment Act of 1971 saw the High Court transfer control over the Temple to a trust managed by the appointees of the State Government of Kerala. Fortunately, the Supreme Court reversed the verdict of the High Court on 13 July 2020 and upheld the rights of the Travancore Royal Family as well as the authority of the Chief Tantri on religious matters.

column3: The Supreme Court's decision to reverse the verdict of the High Court and uphold the rights of the Travancore Royal Family and the authority of the Chief Tantri on religious matters in relation to the temple is an important milestone in India's history. The State Government of Kerala was managed by the appointees of the State Government. My involvement in this case required me to understand the nature of religious rights and the ramifications of such rights on the temple. This case also highlights the importance of religious freedom and its implications for the society.

column3: The Travancore Royal Family and Chief Tantri of India had a major court victory on July 13th, 2020. The court upheld their rights relating to religious matters, especially in relation to temple affairs. This case involved an understanding of the nature of Hindu princely states prior to their integration with the Indian Union and the relationship between the heads of Hindu princely states and the Indian Union.

column3: The integration of Hindu princely states with the Indian Union was a difficult process. [46769] It required understanding of the relationship between the heads of Hindu princely states and their titular deities, as well as the terms and conditions of integration. [46898] Additionally, the nature of Hindu princely states prior to integration was also important to understand. [47029]

column3:
1. The integration of Hindu princely states into the Indian Union is an important part of the Indian history. [46898]
2. Hindu princely states had a unique relationship with their titular deities. [47029]
3. The circumstances, terms and conditions of the integration of Hindu princely states into the Indian Union are an important part of the Indian history. [47158]
4. The 26th Amendment to the Constitution of India is an important milestone in the history of the Indian Union. [47158]
5. The issue of state-level autonomy in India is a recurring one. [47158]

column3: India's history is filled with fascinating stories of Hindu princely states and their titular deities. The integration of these states with the Union of India was a complex process requiring various terms and conditions. The 26th Amendment to the Constitution changed the nature of state control over temples. Working on these matters of constitutional and civilizational significance has been a unique experience.

column3: During this momentous period between August and December 2019, the 26th Amendment to the Constitution was passed. This amendment, which granted 18-year-olds the right to vote, was a major victory for civil rights. The Union also played a crucial role in the history surrounding the amendment and the ongoing issue of State control of temples. Working on matters of constitutional and civilization significance prepared us to make sense of what was to transpire during this time.

column3: The period between August and December 2019 was a momentous period for India. Amendments were made to Articles 367 and 370 of the Constitution on 5 and 6 August. These amendments were aimed at providing greater autonomy to the people of Jammu and Kashmir. This was the first time in India's history that such a constitutional amendment had been made. The experience of working on such matters of constitutional and civilizational significance prepared citizens to make sense of what transpired during this period.

column3: The Indian Constitution underwent two major changes between August and December 2019. With the amendments to Articles 367 and 370 on 5 and 6 August 2019, the erstwhile State of Jammu and Kashmir was reorganized into two Union Territories with effect from 31 October 2019.[47417] This momentous period, which has significant implications for the Indian political landscape, also saw the introduction of the Citizenship Amendment Act on 11 December 2019.[47545] These developments have been crucial in altering the socio-political dynamics of the country.[47674]

column3:
1. India saw major changes in its constitution with the amendment to Articles 367 and 370 of the Constitution on 5 and 6 August 2019, leading to the reorganization of the State of Jammu and Kashmir into two Union Territories with effect from 31 October 2019 [47545]. 
2. The Supreme Court of India, headed by the then Chief Justice of India, Shri Ranjan Gogoi, unanimously pronounced its verdict on the constitutional validity of the reorganization [47674]. 
3. This reorganization of Jammu and Kashmir has been widely praised as a major accomplishment in the history of Indian constitutionalism [47802].

column3: The Supreme Court of India, led by then Chief Justice Ranjan Gogoi, on 9 November 2019 unanimously affirmed the ownership of Shri Ram Lalla over His birthplace in Ayodhya, thus validating the reorganisation of the erstwhile State of Jammu and Kashmir into two Union Territories with effect from 31 October 2019.[47674] This verdict marked a major milestone in India's history, proving the nation's commitment to justice and the rule of law.[47802] The judgement was welcomed by people from all walks of life, who celebrated the resolution of a centuries-old dispute that had been a source of tension in the region.[47931]

column3: The Supreme Court of India recently passed a unanimous verdict on 9 November 2019 affirming the ownership of the Deity Shri Ram Lalla over his birthplace in Ayodhya, thereby validating a 500-year-old Indian civilizational and religious movement to reclaim Shri Ram Janmabhoomi. This verdict comes just a few months after the passing of the Citizenship Amendment Act, 2019, which has stirred up political and religious tensions across the country.

column3: The Supreme Court of India's verdict on 9 November 2019 affirming the ownership of Shri Ram Lalla over his birthplace in Ayodhya, has validated a 500-year-old Indic civilisation and religious movement to reclaim Shri Ram Janmabhoomi. The Citizenship Amendment Act, 2019 (‘the CAA’) was promulgated on 12 December 2019, which provided accelerated access to citizenship for persecuted Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christians from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan. #AyodhyaVerdict #CAA

column3: The Citizenship Amendment Act, 2019 [48062] (‘the CAA’) was promulgated on 12 December 2019 to provide accelerated access to citizenship for persecuted Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christians from Muslim-majority countries such as Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan [48193]. The act is part of a 5 year old Indian civilizational and religious movement to reclaim Shri Ram Janmabhoomi [48326].

column3: The CAA [48193] has been a highly controversial piece of legislation, with many claiming that it discriminates against Muslims and other minorities. The Act grants accelerated access to citizenship for persecuted Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christians from Muslim-majority countries such as Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan [48326]. This has sparked a heated debate online and in the media, as it is seen as a drastic shift in Indian history [48457].

column3: The religious diversity of India has been a source of debate among Buddhists, Jains, Parsis, and Christians from Muslim-majority countries like Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan. These debates have touched upon various fault lines and unresolved legacy and civilizational issues. The most troubling aspect of these debates is that they often bring out deep-seated prejudices and misunderstandings between different religious groups. This has been evident in the public discourse around the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in India, which has been seen by many as a discriminatory policy towards Muslims.

column3: The European colonizers had a dramatic impact on the identity and consciousness of the nation when they set foot on its soil. Arguments rooted in the Constitution were used to support these positions, thus turning the Constitution into a battleground. The divide was so vast that people were using social media to express their dissent. It is clear that the European colonizers had a lasting effect on the nation's identity and the way it interacts with the Constitution.

column3: The ongoing debate over the use of 'Bharat' and 'India' to refer to our nation has taken a divisive turn, with arguments rooted in the Constitution being used to support both sides. Social media users have claimed that the use of 'Bharat' goes against the Constitution's promise of secularism [49103]. Article 1 of the Constitution states that India is a "Union of States" [49356], suggesting that 'India' is the more appropriate term. This debate is a reminder of the importance of the Constitution and its impact on our nation's identity.

column3: The divisive nature of the Constitution of India has been highlighted by the heated debates on social media surrounding the use of ‘Bharat’ for India. Despite Article 1 of the Constitution beginning with ‘India, that is Bharat’ to emphasize its roots and heritage, this fact was largely overlooked. Such an omission has led to a divide between citizens, turning the Constitution into a battleground of sorts.

It was a sign of India's commitment to secularism as promised in the Constitution. Unfortunately, the significance of this was largely overlooked and even if it was known, it was rarely appreciated.

column3: The use of ‘Bharat’ in the very first Article of the document has been a source of debate for many years. Through the prisms of civilization and the Constitution, the article examines the relationship between India and Bharat and the significance of this use. It also questions the implications of this relationship to the State and to the society at large. The book explores the long-term implications of the use of ‘Bharat’ and its impact on the citizens of the country.

column3: The relationship between India and Bharat can be seen in the Indian Constitution and its civilizational roots. Recent articles have been written for publications like Firstpost and Open Magazine that argue against simplistic binaries between India and Bharat and emphasize the importance of understanding the nuanced history of the two entities. This shows how the relationship between India and Bharat has evolved over time and how it remains an important factor in today's society.

column3: The Constitution is a powerful document that shapes our society and civilization. It is essential that we understand the Constitution in its broader context, rather than approaching it with a sense of affected and exaggerated religiosity. We must learn to appreciate the history and legacy of the Constitution and its impact on our nation and the world. We must also recognize the importance of civil discourse and dialogue to ensure that our society remains respectful and open to different views and perspectives. #ConstitutionDay #LegalHeritage #CivilDiscourse #Civility #Society

column3: The Constitution of a nation is an integral part of its culture and history. It is important to understand it in the context of its broader civilization in order to properly appreciate its value and significance. [49993] The Constitution should not be approached with a sense of affected and exaggerated religiosity without understanding it in the wider context of the civilization. [50125] It is essential to recognize the primary canvas and object of protection that the Constitution provides. [50254] Furthermore, it should not be romanticized or venerated without a proper understanding of its origin and purpose.

column3: The Constitution is an important part of our civilization and should be approached with understanding and respect. We should not romanticize or exaggerate its religious aspects without understanding the broader context in which it was written. The primary goal of the Constitution is to protect our civilization, and if we forget this, we risk diminishing its impact. We should strive to recognize the importance of the Constitution and its ability to protect our society.

column3: The Constitution must be alive to history to serve its intended purpose. It is essential to understand the primary canvas and object of protection in order to romanticize and venerate the Constitution. This is to ensure the means and the end do not conflict, leading to the detriment of civilization. These were the tentative beginnings on this journey and it is necessary to continue exploring the relationship between Constitution and history.

column3: The Constitution needs to be alive and relevant to serve its purpose. This was the main argument made at a conference in Chennai on the Hindu character of princely States, where it was highlighted that the means must be in line with the end to the benefit of the civilization. This was the starting point of my thoughts on this intersection, and I explored how the Constitution can be used to promote the progress of the nation.

Examining the existing ideological divides across the political spectrum in India can help to better understand the current situation. With many aspects of society changing due to the pandemic, understanding the different ideologies and how they interact can help to create a better society.

column3: The colonial legacy of India has had a lasting impact on its politics and society. [51399] With the recent lockdown providing respite, it is an opportune moment to delve deeper into the ideological divides across the political spectrum in India. [51526] This includes understanding the acceptance of the colonialised version of India’s history, regardless of labels and its implications on matters of human rights, justice, and equality. [51656]

column3: The shared view across ideologies in colonialised version of Bharat's history is that there is a universal and uniform moral standard that all 'civilised societies' must adhere to. This includes matters of human rights, religion, education, environment, development, caste and gender. In addition, there is a recognition of the need to maintain a level of respect for these standards regardless of labels.

column3: The data from the book suggests that there is a universal and uniform moral standard that all ‘civilised societies’ must adhere to. This standard includes topics such as human rights, religion, education, environment, development, caste and gender. Scholars such as Ram Swarup, Sitaram Goel, Dharmapal, Koenraad Elst, Dr. S.N. Balagangadhar and Dr. Jakob De Roover have argued for the existence of such a moral standard.

column3: The book reveals that many scholars have challenged the western-normative framework which informed the so-called "universal standards". [51917] Furthermore, these standards were seen as the moral standard which all "civilised societies" must adhere to. [52047] Even those scholars, such as Ram Swarup, Sitaram Goel, Dharmapal, Koenraad Elst, Dr. S.N. Balagangadhara and Dr. Jakob De Roover, who have researched this claim, have found it difficult to validate. [52180] This suggests that the notion of a "universal moral standard" is questionable. #UniversalStandards #MoralStandards #ChallengeTheNorm

column3: The Indian civilization has been a source of immense spiritual, philosophical, legal and epistemological knowledge. [52047] Scholars such as Ram Swarup, Sitaram Goel, Dharmpal, Koenraad Elst, Dr. S. N. Balagangadhara and Dr. Jakob De Roover have been vocal proponents of the same. [52180] They have challenged the Western-normative framework which informs the so-called universal standards. [52313] Even those who extolled the Indian civilization have seemed more interested in its traditions than in embracing the universal standards.

column3: Many are challenging the Western-normative framework that informs so-called universal standards. Those who praise the Indian civilization for its spiritual, philosophical, legal and epistemological traditions are questioning the selective application of these standards. There is reluctance to challenge the narrow interpretation of supposedly universal standards.

column3: The Indic civilization has been praised for its spiritual, philosophical, legal and epistemological traditions. It is important to note that these traditions have been selectively applied in accordance with a Western-normative framework that does not take into account Indian thought. Critically, this framework fails to accommodate for the ontological and theological nuances of the Indic worldview.

column3: The West's selective application of supposedly universal standards, and their refusal to accommodate Indic thought, have had long-reaching consequences for non-Western civilizations like Bharat. Through an examination of the ontological and theological origins of the Western-normative framework, we can better understand the impact of this framework on civilizations outside of the West.

column3: The Western-normative framework has had a significant effect on non-Western civilizations, such as Bharat, which refused to accommodate Indic thought. This framework is rooted in colonial stereotypes that lack scrutiny and examination. Despite this, it has been widely accepted and perpetuated, leading to a lack of recognition and understanding of Indic thought and beliefs.

column3: The origins of this framework and their effect on non-Western civilizations, such as Bharat, have not been given the attention they deserve. Despite the seemingly opposing sides (or ‘wings’) of the Indic civilization, the same reservoir of colonial stereotypes have been liberally used by both sides. This highlights the need for further research and discussion on the impact of this framework on non-Western civilizations.

column3: The colonial stereotypes about the Indian civilisation have been challenged by both sides of the debate, with one side reinforcing the stereotypes to make the case that there was no connection between India and Bhārat, while the other side highlighted the very connections. This has piqued the attention of many, warranting further examination.

column3: The book dives into the seemingly opposing sides of Bharat and India, and how they are deeply connected. It explores the idea of a "liberal Bharat" and how it is open to different cultural influences. It further discusses the stereotypes that exist between the two countries and how they can be challenged. The book ultimately argues for a new idea of India that is both inclusive and progressive.

column3: The book mentions two different perspectives on the connection between Bhart and India. The first one is that there is no connection between the two, while the other highlights the openness of Bhart to new ideas and reform. This suggests that Bhart is a hub of open-mindedness and innovation, which can be used to create a new India. This open-mindedness can be a major factor in bringing about positive changes in the country. #OpenMindedness #Innovation #Bhart #India #Reform.

column3: India is a country that has embraced openness and new ideas, from its rich history to its modern-day reforms. It has been able to break away from the same stereotypical views and create a ‘liberal’ Bharat. This new idea of India, as cited by Bharat’s innate openness, has been further championed by the Indian consciousness and its repackaged version of the Reformation, the Indian Reformation. India is a vibrant nation that continues to strive for progress and reform.

column3: The Reformation had a strong influence on the emergence of new ideas and reform movements. The former, at least, wore its antipathy to the Indic consciousness openly. The message being evangelized by the latter was a repackaged version of the Reformation, in this case an Indic Reformation. Of course, this school of thought pursued its Reformationist agenda while paying lip-service to Bharat and its civilizational character.

column3: The Indian Reformation was repackaged and evangelized by the latter school of thought, which pursued its own Reformist agenda while paying tokenism to Bharat and its civilizational character. This was a critical layer in the national discourse which needed to be unpacked to placate the larger Indic society.

column3: The Reformist agenda in India has been largely overlooked, but its impact on the Indian civilization is undeniable. [53612] Its tokenism has been used to placate the larger Indian society, while relegating the goals of reclaiming Indic civilizational consciousness and agency over it. [53741] This critical layer in the national discourse needs to be unpacked to ensure that the larger goals of the Reformist agenda are met. [53871]

column3: [53741] The larger Indic society was appeased with tokenism in the national discourse in order to reclaim Indic civilizational consciousness and agency over it. [53871] However, this goal was being relegated to the margins by both sides for different reasons, leading to the same net result — Bhart would continue to operate within the same colonial framework. [54000] This colonial framework was necessary to maintain the status quo and prevent any meaningful transformation of society.

column3: The reclaiming of Indian civilization consciousness and agency is being relegated to the margins by both sides for different reasons. This results in India continuing to operate within the colonizer's framework without any real and lasting impact on Indian civilization. This highlights the importance of reclaiming India's cultural identity and agency, to ensure it is not forgotten.

column3: The net result of the colonization of India was the same - Bharat continued to operate within the colonizer's framework, without any real and lasting impact on policy making. This could have a negative impact on Bharat's economic aspirations since the promise of an Indic Renaissance would be limited to symbolic and ornamental use.

column3: The coloniser's framework has had a significant effect on policymaking in India, even though its civilizational character is mainly symbolic and ornamental. The premise of an Indian Renaissance, that is, re-inscribing indigenous consciousness onto contemporary India, was not necessary for India's economic aspirations. The significance of this framework and India's future outlook is highly important.

column3: The premise of an Indic Reclamation in Bharat has major implications on policy making [54259]. This suggests that it is not necessary for Bharat to adhere to the Western rules to achieve economic prosperity [54390]. Rather, a civilizational reclamation can be beneficial for the nation's economic aspirations [54520].

column3: [54390] India's economic progress can be achieved by re-inscribing the indigenous consciousness into contemporary Bharat, instead of playing by the West's rules. [54520] A civilizational reclamation has the potential to boost originality of thought and confidence, leading to economic progress in an unconventional way. [54648] This, in turn, could pave the way for a more sustainable and creative approach to economic development in Bharat. #IndigenousConsciousness #EconomicProgress #Bharat #WestRules

column3: The pursuit of economic prosperity need not be done by following the West's rules. Instead, it can be achieved through a civilization reclamation that values a balanced approach to nature and development. Confidence and originality of thought can be fostered in this way, paving the way for economic progress that is consistent with Indic ethos.

column3: [54648] The potential of spurring confidence and originality of thought can pave the way for economic progress that is consistent with Indian ethos, which values a balanced approach to nature and development. [54779] Pursuing economic prosperity through the mere imitation of a Western framework would cement the notion that the only viable way was to adhere to Western standards. [54907] This could lead to a limited understanding of the needs of the Indian population and inhibit the potential for economic growth.

column3: The pursuit of economic prosperity through the mere imitation of a Western framework would have irreversible and catastrophic consequences for the survival of India's indigeneity. According to ancient Indic ethos, a balanced approach to nature and development should be valued to protect our cultural heritage. We should strive to create a sustainable future that preserves our traditional values while also embracing the advantages of modernity.

column3: The Western framework of imitation has been seen as the only viable way, but this could have irreversible and catastrophic consequences for the survival of India’s indigeneity. It would be unwise to keep economics and civilization in separate compartments because there is a relationship between the two.

column3: The relationship between economics and civilization should not be isolated in walled gardens. The average person is likely to attribute the West's economic progress to its cultural influence, which could have irreversible and catastrophic consequences for the survival of Bharat's indigenous identity. We should be wary of this western way of thinking and be open to alternative approaches.

column3: It is important to recognize that economics and civilization are intertwined. The West's economic prosperity is largely due to the values and ideals it subscribes to, as well as its ontology and theology. Moreover, it would be unwise to put these two forces in a silo-based approach as the average person is likely to attribute the West's economic growth to the connection between economics and civilization. #West #Economics #Civilization #Prosperity

column3: The West's economic prosperity is attributed to the values and ideals it subscribes to, and ultimately to its onto-epistemology and theology (OET). We must recognize and respect the rightful place of Indic thought in this discourse. We must also be mindful of the risks associated with a silo-based approach to decision-making. The average person should be encouraged to consider the wider implications of their decisions.

column3: The power struggle between the Big Powers to ensure respect for Indic thought is a key theme in the book. The ultimate goal is to preserve the sacred middle ground between the seemingly opposing camps and to end all civilizational enquiry regardless of which side of the ideological divide one is on. This is a timely reminder of the importance of civilizational dialogue in our current socio-political landscape.

column3: [55683] Maybe the true objective is to maintain the balance between the seemingly opposing camps and preserve the status quo? [55813] Could it be that there is an unwritten code that all civilizations abide by, regardless of which side of the ideological divide one is on? [55941] Perhaps this code is the sacred middle ground where all civilizational enquiry ends?

column3: The [55813] result speaks of a "sacred middle ground" where all civilizational inquiry ends regardless of which side of the ideological divide one is on. The [55941] result speaks of an unwritten code that allows the envelope on the civilizational front to be pushed only so far, thus maintaining the hegemony of the West. The [56069] result speaks of the West's dominance within a global context, where its ideas and beliefs are the standard. This highlights that the West has an influence that reaches beyond its own borders, even if it isn't necessarily acknowledged. #IdeologicalDivide #WestDominance #GlobalInfluence #CivilizationalInquiry

column3: The idea of an "unwritten code" that keeps the hegemony of Western-normative framework in Indian discourse is quite interesting. It explains the unquestionable deference with which the framework is being accepted. The implication of such a code is that there are certain boundaries that can't be crossed in order to maintain the status quo. This could lead to an interesting discussion about the power structures at play in Indian discourse.

column3: The hegemony of the West has been challenged by the emergence of a new, stern-normative framework in Indian discourse. This framework has been embraced by those who stand for a living civilization, placing a premium on self-confidence and critical inquiry. The envelope on civilization has been pushed only so far, reminding us of the power of the West to shape the discourse.

column3: India has long been known for its rich culture and traditions, and its discourse often reflects this. [56202] Stern-normative framework is a concept that is widely accepted in Indian discourse and is often accepted unquestioningly, even by those who claim to stand for a living civilization that places a premium on self-confidence and critical inquiry. [56331] This led to the view that it was important for people to understand that Bharat, as a civilization, was a product of its own unique history and values, and not simply a reflection of Western ideals. [56458] Understanding this framework is essential to understanding Indian discourse and participating in meaningful conversations.

column3: The book data talks about how people tend to reduce the reality and near-unbroken lived experience of Bharat as a civilization to mere talking points to gain brownie points. Even those who claim to stand for a living civilization that places a premium on self-confidence, critical enquiry and truth are guilty of this. It's important to understand that Bharat as a civilization is a reality and going beyond mere talk can help preserve the same. #Bharat #Civilization #SelfConfidence #CriticalEnquiry #Truth

column3: The Indian civilization is an ancient and complex one, and it is important to understand the historical context in which it exists. [56458] Questions such as “What is the truth?” can lead to the realization that reducing the lived experience of India to a talking point for scoring brownie points is not a true reflection of the values the Indian civilization stands for. [56587] It is more a proof of expediency than a sign of real conviction in the values this culture holds. [56715] This calls for a deeper exploration of the Indian civilization in order to truly understand its values and history.

[56715] Despite this, the Indic civilization still has the capacity to offer a credible and viable alternative to the Western-normative framework. [56844] This alternative could be a valuable asset, as it could challenge the status quo and offer an innovative perspective.

column3: India's Indic civilization had more to do with expediency than real conviction in its values. Despite not believing in its capacity to provide a credible and viable alternative to the Western-normative framework, the rest of the world still looks up to India as the ‘Vishwaguru’, meaning ‘world teacher’. India has an impressive legacy of knowledge and spiritual practices that should be honoured and respected.

We must look to them as teachers and guides, so that we can embrace the courage of our convictions and live according to our own values. By doing so, we can become beacons of hope and inspiration to others. [57097]

column3: The rise of national icons like Swami Vivekananda and Sri Aurobindo has highlighted the importance of every culture contributing to the global pool of thought. Recasting Bharat in the mould of the West would kill its originality and character, leaving it a mere vassal of the West after the European coloniser had left its shores. This emphasizes the need to preserve our cultures and not be influenced by outside forces.

column3: The Global Pool of Thought is an important concept to understand the originality and character of Bharat. We must recognize the tragedy that would come if we were to recast Bharat into the mold of the West, a tragedy of incalculable proportions for which we would have no one to blame but ourselves. To bring out the unconscious and unspoken ideas of the East, we must understand the Global Pool of Thought and ensure that Bharat remains true to its own roots.

column3: The West has long been seen as the standard of progress and development, but the data from the book suggests that this may be an unconscious and unshakeable belief across the political and ideological spectrum. The text gives examples of countries that have been left behind after European colonization, highlighting a tragedy of incalculable proportions that we have no one to blame but ourselves for. It also implies that this same Western-normative framework has been used to evaluate the type and character of other nations, making them mere vassals of the West.

column3: The Western-normative framework is being embraced across the political and ideological spectrum, leading to a search for similar movements in other societies. India's quest for cultural decolonization is an example, as highlighted by the scholarly works of Dr. Balagangadhar and Dr. De Roover. In addition, two key reasons for exploring India's cultural decolonization are the need to understand the power dynamics between colonizers and colonized and the need to challenge existing Eurocentric narratives.

This research highlights the far-reaching consequences of colonial power and the importance of understanding the history of colonialism.

column3: The globalization of European colonialism and Western imperialism has had a major impact on contemporary India, evidenced by the scholarly work of Dr. Balagangadhar and Dr. De Roover on colonial consciousness. This work has demonstrated the presence of such consciousness on a global scale, with India seeking global validation of its position. As a result, it is clear that European colonialism and Western imperialism still have an enduring impact on India today.

column3: The Ongoing Debates surrounding the Constitution provide a great opportunity to explore various perspectives on the subject. One such perspective is the historical school of jurisprudence, popularized by the works of Friedrich Karl von Savigny, Georg Friedrich Puchta, and Henry Maine. This school of thought provides an alternative to the Eurocentric framework as it can be applied to societies that have experienced colonization, such as India.

column3: The colonial experience of India, known as Bharat, is a multifaceted phenomenon with similarities and differences in comparison to other countries. It is important to examine the transgenerational trauma of this experience in order to better understand its effects. A non-Eurocentric framework that is applicable to societies that have experienced colonialism is necessary in order to gain perspective on this trauma. Such a framework must be malleable and conducive to the Indian worldview in order to be effective.

column3: It is evident that the colonial experience of India, while sharing certain similarities with other colonized societies, also had its own unique aspects. My objective was to gain a deeper understanding of the Indic civilization on its own terms, utilizing its own lexicon, warts and all. Furthermore, extending the application of this framework to my own personal journey in understanding the Indic civilization was also a part of this endeavor.

In April 2020, I was approached to speak on the Indian Constitution and its framework in a concrete manner [59815]. However, lacking formal training in this area of humanities, my search for a framework was not aided [59942]. By exploring the law and the Constitution in more detail, I was able to develop my own framework [60068].

column3: The Indian Constitution is of great importance to the polity of Bharat. [59942] My search for a framework was not helped by the fact that I lacked formal training in this area of humanities. [60068] However, in April 2020, I was approached to speak on the Indian Constitution at a webinar meant for Indian Americans. [60199] This gave me the opportunity to learn more about the Indian Constitution and its implications for Indian Americans. Dr. Indu Viswanathan, a Hindu-American scholar and educator, was present at the webinar and provided valuable insights into the Indian Constitution.

In April 2020, Dr. Indu Viswanathan was invited to speak on the Indian Constitution at a webinar meant for Indian Americans. After the webinar, Dr. Viswanathan's brainchild remarked that the work on reconciling the Constitution with Indic civilization's perspectives was truly inspiring.

column3: [60460] Decolonality in action is a concept that was introduced by the author, which suggests that societies have witnessed a shift from colonization to decolonization. [60590] The author urged readers to explore decolonality to understand its relevance to the Indian position. [60717] Through the author's work, readers can gain an understanding of the struggle faced by colonized societies and the steps they can take to reclaim their identity and sovereignty.

Walsh and Nelson Maldonado-Torres are shedding light on the applicability of decolonality to the similarly placed societies witnessed in the past.[60590] From understanding the Indic position to exploring the literature, these authors are providing valuable insight into the subject.[60717] Their works are helping to recognize and address the oppression that has been felt for centuries.[60847]

column3: The study of coloniality has been deeply explored by brilliant scholars like Torres, Dr. Viswanathan, and Ms. Sumita Amabasta. Their work sheds light on colonial language policies and the writings of Arturo Escobar, whose insights into the relationship between coloniality and 'development' are essential for development professionals in Bharat. Exploring these issues further, we can gain a better understanding of the impacts that colonialism has on modern day.

column3: This book sheds light on colonial language policies, and the writings of Arturo Escobar whose perspectives on the relationship between coloniality and ‘development’ are essential for development professionals in Bharat. As explored in the book, ‘coloniality’, first conceptualised by Latin-American scholar Aníbal Quijano, informed the European colonisation of Latin America and consequently the development policies of the region.

column3: Coloniality is a concept that has been long used to explain the power dynamics between colonisers and colonised. It is increasingly being recognised as a key factor in understanding the unequal structures of ‘development’. [61240] Coloniality was first conceptualised by Latin American scholar Aníbal Quijano and it is seen as the basis for European colonisers to exploit the world and maintain their power. [61372] This relationship between coloniality and ‘development’ needs to be studied further in order to understand the power dynamics and inequalities that exist in our world today. [61500] #Development #Coloniality #PowerDynamics #UnequalStructures #AníbalQuijano

column3: Coloniality is a concept developed by Aníbal Quijano to explain the European coloniser’s use of power and exploitation of the world. It was rooted in the coloniser’s religious beliefs that gave them a sense of racial superiority. Coloniality was the basis and justification for the European colonisation of the world. It has had far-reaching consequences on the world, leading to political, economic, social, and cultural power imbalances between those who are colonised and those who are not.

column3: Colonialism was rooted in the colonizer’s religious beliefs and his sense of racial superiority that placed the Christian White European colonizer at the top of the world order. This sense of superiority was the basis and justification for the exploitation of the world. Coloniality was the fountain of European colonialism, which in turn was the very foundation of the colonizer’s use of power.

column3: Colonialism was rooted in the religious beliefs of the colonizer, which created the idea of racial superiority. This sense of superiority was seen as both a divinely ordained right and a scientific fact, leading to the formation of racial hierarchies. Europeans were placed at the top of the world order, and this perpetuated the belief that they were superior to other races.

column3: The European colonizer was driven by a sense of superiority, leading to the creation of racial hierarchies all over the world. Colonality reshaped the concept of history and time by creating constructs such as 'modernity' and 'raciality' that can still be seen today. This colonization had a major impact on the world order, placing the Christian White European colonizer at the top.

column3: Colonization had a major impact on the world, reshaping the concept of history and time through the creation of constructs such as ‘modernity’ and ‘nationality’. European colonizers treated colonization as a divinely ordained right and scientific fact, which resulted in the establishment of racial hierarchies around the world. These hierarchies are still present in contemporary everyday conversations, often without knowledge of their colonial origins.

column3: The coloniality of power has transformed the concept of history and time, creating constructs such as 'modernity' and 'rationality' which are now commonly used without knowledge of their colonial origins. This colonial matrix has had the effect of erasing the cultural experience of many people around the world. It is important to understand the implications of this coloniality of power and to recognize its lasting effects on our present society. #Coloniality #Modernity #Rationality #History #Time

column3: The colonial matrix of power and its integral role in both modernity and rationalism had a profound effect on the cultural experiences and subjectivities of colonized societies, as evidenced by the loose use of words such as 'nationality' in everyday conversations. This has resulted in the erasure of the histories of these societies, with the colonizer believing their histories only began once they arrived.

column3: The power matrix of modernity and rationality had the effect of negating the cultural experience and subjectivities of colonized societies, creating a need for 'decolonality' to counter the Eurocentric/Western-normative framework. Decolonality is the response to coloniality, and literature has taught us that it is essential for understanding the effects of colonization.

column3: Decolonization is a process of undoing the damage caused by colonialism and restoring the rights of colonized societies. Through decolonization, colonized societies gain a sense of sovereignty and autonomy, which enables them to regain control of their own history and culture. The literature taught me that decolonization is a response to colonialism and the Eurocentric/Western-normative framework imposed by the European colonizer. Decolonization aims to unshackle formerly colonized societies from the oppressive structures of colonialism and reclaim their individual and collective identities.

column3: Decolonality is the response to colonialism and Eurocentric/Western-normative frameworks introduced in colonized societies by the European colonizers. It seeks to unshackle these societies from the totalizing universalisms of European colonialism and its current-day successor, Western imperialism, so that agency and self-determination can be returned to the colonized people. Decolonality is an important concept for understanding the dynamics of colonialism and imperialism and their effects on people and cultures. #Decolonality #Colonialism #Imperialism #SelfDetermination

column3: Decolonization is the process of undoing the damaging impact of European colonialism on formerly colonized societies. It seeks to restore the agency and dignity of these societies that were previously denied by their colonizers. People who have experienced or are currently experiencing colonialism are reclaiming their identities and striving to create a more equitable and just world order. #Decolonization #Colonialism #Justice #Equity #Identity #Freedom.

column3: Colonial consciousness has been an underlying theme throughout the literature on colonialism and its modern successor, Western imperialism. [62808] The Totalising Universalisms of European colonialism has been explored to understand how agency and dignity can be restored to those affected by it. [62936] There appears to be an implicit handshake between literature on colonialism and the works of Dr. Balagangadhara and Dr. De Roover on colonial consciousness. [63067] This connection has shed light on the far-reaching effects of colonialism and the importance of recognizing its legacy in contemporary society. #Colonialism #Imperialism #Agency #Dignity

column3: Colonial consciousness is a term that has been discussed by scholars such as Dr. Balagangadhara and Dr. De Rover in their works. They emphasize the importance of dignity and awareness in regards to coloniality. It is suggested that the framework of colonial consciousness deserves serious consideration, whether or not it holds all the answers. The more literature on coloniality is read, the more the significance of this concept becomes apparent.

column3: [63067] Colonial consciousness has been studied extensively by scholars such as Dr. Balagangadhar and Dr. De Roover. Their work has highlighted the inadvertent handshake between literature and colonial consciousness. [63194] The framework of literature and colonial consciousness could be seriously considered as a potential source of answers for contemporary Bharat. [63326] This framework has also highlighted the double standards concerning colonial consciousness-related questions.

It also highlights the double standards that are applied to decolonial movements in other decolonized societies [63326]. Moreover, the framework provides an analysis of the Indic movement for cultural and political reform in the modern context [63455], allowing for a deeper understanding of the various issues at play.

column3: The contemporary Bharat is facing multiple business-related questions, such as the double standards that are being applied to decolonization movements in other decolonized societies on one hand, and the Indic movement for cultural decolonization and reclaiming of its civilizational identity on the other. These double standards have been met with serious and positive attention, but the Indic movement has received relatively little attention. This highlights the need for further exploration into the business-related questions that the contemporary Bharat is facing.

column3: The hypocrisy of the colonial movement in other de-colonised societies has been evident with the positive reception of the former and the negative reception of the Indian movement for cultural decolonisation and reclamation of its civilisational identity. This double standard has been criticised for branding the Indian movement as illiberal, xenophobic and lacking a historical basis. This issue needs to be addressed to create a more balanced approach to decolonisation.

column3: The decolonization and reclamation of its civilizational identity is a major topic in the book. It has been seen that while the former has received serious and positive attention, the latter has been branded as illiberal, xenophobic, and lacking a historical basis. This hypocrisy needs to be addressed and the book provides an insightful look into the interplay between decolonization and the reclamation of civilizational identity. The book also highlights the importance of understanding the implications of such a process and the need for a more nuanced approach to the issue.

This column has been lauded for its ability to call out the hypocrisy of those branded as illiberal, xenophobic and lacking in historical basis. column3: I have been writing the 'Indic Views' column for The Daily Guardian since May 2020. The column focuses on the interplay between civilization and the Constitution, viewed through the lens of decolonization. It has received positive feedback for its innovative approach to constitutionalism. After writing close to 18 pieces under the column, I am now confident that I can contribute to a meaningful discussion about constitutionalism and decolonization.

column3: The upcoming book [63975] "Civilization and the Constitution Approached Through The Lens of Decolonization" dives deep into the intersection of colonalism, civilization, and the Constitution. The book, written by an early September 2020 column, has received positive feedback for its take on an innovative approach to constitutionalism. This book promises to explore the convergence between colonialism, civilization, and the Constitution, exploring the impact of colonialism on our laws and our society.

column3: The book offers a new approach to constitutionalism, discussing the convergence between colonialism, civilization and the Constitution. It also provides a fresh, timely, and nuanced conversation on the subject from the perspective of a genuine and committed learner. The book is a great resource for those looking for a deeper understanding of the subject.

column3: This book looks closely at the convergences between coloniality, civilisation and the Constitution of India. It is written by an expert, but also a genuine and committed learner. The aim is to create an open and nuanced conversation about Bharat and the issues it faces. In October 2020, the author began writing this book, which is the first of its kind in India. It is a unique and timely exploration of the relationship between coloniality, civilisation and the Constitution.

column3: The book explores the effects of European colonial consciousness and coloniality, particularly its religious and racial implications, on Bharat. It also encourages timely and nuanced conversations about Bharat on these issues [64360]. It is written by an expert and enthusiastic learner, hoping to start fresh conversations about coloniality and its effects [64486]. The book is part of the Bharat trilogy which examines the influence of European colonial consciousness and coloniality [64618].

column3: This book, [64486], explores the influence of European colonial consciousness/coloniality on Bharat, its religious and racial roots, and the origins of the Indian Constitution. [64618] It lays out the complex history of Bharat, from ancient to modern times, and how it has been affected by European colonialism. [64746] It also examines the contemporary debates around Bharat, the role of caste, gender, and religion, and how these issues are shaping the future of the nation. #Bharat #Colonialism #History #IndianConstitution

column3: The Age of Discovery, marked by Christopher Columbus’ expedition in 1492, is explored in the Bharti trilogy as the foundation of its sequels. It examines the impact of European colonialism on Bharti civilization, specifically looking at its religious and racial roots. The trilogy ultimately leads to the origins of the Indian Constitution.

column3: The book "Cial Roots, On Bharat As The Successor State To The Indic Civilization And The Origins Of The Indian Constitution" covers the period between the Age of Discovery and the reshaping of Bharat through a British-made Constitution - the Government of India Act of 1919. It provides a comprehensive overview of the transformation of Bharat from the pre-colonial era to the post-independence era. The book also examines the legacy of the British Raj and its impact on the nation's political, economic and social development. It sheds light on the process of nation-building and the evolution of the Indian Constitution, highlighting the role of key individuals in the process.

column3: The book [64877] Foundation for its Sequels covers the period between the Age of Discovery and the reshaping of Bharat through the Government of India Act of 1919. The book is split into three sections - Coloniality, Civilization, and Constitution - with the third section focusing on the ultimate objective of the author's attention. It gives an in-depth look at how the colonial rule affected the culture, society, and politics of India. It also examines the impact of the British-made Constitution on the nation and how it shaped the modern-day Bharat.

column3: The Government of India Act of 1919 reshaped India and its relationship with the British Empire. It brought changes in the colonial framework, shifted the focus to the civilizational aspects of India, and ultimately resulted in the formation of a constitution. This book looks at the implications of this Act and how it shaped present-day India. [65004] It examines the coloniality of India and its colonial consciousness, and how this has been impacted by the British-made constitution. [65137] It also looks at how the Act has had a global impact, and how it has been instrumental in reshaping India. [65268]

column3: Coloniality, Civilization, and Constitution are the three main sections of the book. The first section deals with a global perspective, while the second and third sections focus on colonial consciousness and coloniality in India. The book provides a wealth of information about the effects of colonialism on Indian society and how it can be addressed. The third section also examines the constitutional framework of the country and how it has been shaped by colonialism. The book is an important source of information for understanding the complexities of colonialism and its implications for modern India.

column3: The book discusses the impact of colonialism and colonial consciousness on the Constitution of India. It examines the in-depth analysis of coloniality and colonial consciousness in the second and third sections, which helps to understand the effects of colonialism on Indian society. In the first section, it provides a global perspective on the issue and delves deeper into the Indian context in the later parts. It also provides an abundance of standalone literature on the subject, which helps to gain a thorough understanding of the Constitution and its implications.

This framework was the foundation for examination of the Constitution for Colonies [65788] and has had a lasting impact on the discussion surrounding colonialism.

column3: Colonial consciousness has been a pervasive force in the history of the world, playing an integral role in the Age of Discovery and its subsequent sequels. The Age of Discovery, beginning with Christopher Columbus’s expedition in 1492, was driven by religious inspirations and racial underpinnings. This period saw the emergence of a Eurocentric, Western-normative framework which had a lasting impact on the subsequent centuries of global history. The literature on coloniality offers insight into the ways in which this framework has been adapted and adopted in various contexts.

column3: The Age of Discovery, which began with Christopher Columbus’ expedition in 1492, has had a profound impact on modern European/Western-normative frameworks. It is believed to have been inspired by religious motivations and racial underpinnings, and has resulted in the subjugation of colonized societies and the rise of decolonization as a response. I have examined this phenomenon in detail, exploring its implications on rationality and its effects on colonized societies.

column3: The arrival of Christopher Columbus to the Americas in 1492 marked the beginning of the colonial era, one which had a lasting impact on nature, religion, language, knowledge, education, law and the emergence of nation-state. His expedition was driven by religious inspiration and racial subjugation, and caused a shift in modernity and rationality. The colonial era has been noted for its detrimental effects on colonized societies, including the displacement of native people and the destruction of their culture. The Westphalian origin of the 'nation-state' system has been linked to the colonial period, as it served to legitimize and enforce the subjugation of colonized populations.

column3: Colonialism has had a profound impact on societies around the world. From the rise of decolonization as a response to its rationalization and its effects on nature, religion, language, knowledge, education, and law, it is clear that colonialism has had a far-reaching impact. In particular, the Latin American roots of decolonization scholarship has focused primarily on European colonialism and its legacy. Moreover, the Westphalian origin of the nation-state further highlights the impact of colonialism on global societies.

column3: Coloniality has a major impact on aspects like nature, religion, language, knowledge, education and law. It has shaped the Westphalian concept of the nation-state. The Latin American origin of decolonial scholarship has limited its vision to focus only on European coloniality. It is essential for every society to identify and recognize their own colonial legacy and how it has shaped their current status. Understanding the impacts of coloniality can help us create more inclusive and equitable societies.

column3: Decolonization is an essential process for societies to identify and address the forms of colonialism they have been subjected to. This process can be difficult to navigate, and is often overlooked due to the focus of European colonial scholarship on Latin America. It is important for all societies to recognize and understand their colonial history, and outline the contours of their decolonization. #Decolonization #ColonialHistory #LatinAmerica

From the book, it is evident that colonialism has caused Bharat to identify the forms of colonization it has been subjected to, and outline for itself the contours of its decoloniality. The book also suggests that every society should do the same in order to work towards decoloniality. [66442]

column3: The impact of European colonisation on Bhart has been far-reaching, spanning from religion, caste, tribe, education and political infrastructure. It has changed the form of colonisation that Bhart has been subjected to, and outlined for itself the contours of its decolonisation. The period between 1600 and 1853 saw changes in the way Bhart was structured, with religion, caste, tribe, education and political infrastructure all being affected. These changes have had a lasting impact on Bhart and its people, and are still being felt today.

column3: In the realm of religion, caste, tribe, education and political infrastructure, between 1600 and 1853, the concept of ‘tolerance’, ‘secularism’ and ‘humanism’ originally stemmed from Christian political theology. The subsequent role of these constructs in subverting the indigenous Indian consciousness through a secularised and universalised Reformative movement is an important part of history.

It further examines their subsequent role in subverting the indigenous Indic consciousness through a secularised and universalised Reformation. Additionally, the concept of Middle Eastern coloniality since Middle Eastern colonisation of Bharat is also discussed.

column3: The Middle Eastern colonization of Bharat predates the European variant and has had a lasting effect on Indian consciousness. Subsequent roles of iCAL theology have been instrumental in subverting the indigenous Indic consciousness through a secularized and universalized Reformation. This concept of Middle Eastern coloniality is an important aspect of Bharat's version of decoloniality which must address both forms of coloniality.
